description: Cyber security Engineer in support of DoD, DISA, NIST, Marine Corps, Air Force, and Naval IA programs. Mr. Creighton provided senior leadership and guidance to a series of IA related projects including: Information Assurance consultant to the DISA PEO-STS SATCOM Broadband Global Area Network (BGAN) acquisition program manager; co-lead management oversight and technical support for the DoD Cyber Security and IA (CSIA) Science and Technology Roadmap Task Force; IA task technical lead in the Joint MRAP II C & A process; member of the GBS Joint Program Office system engineering and integration team supporting senior government leadership within the GBS JPO. This included applying DIACAP policy and procedures, IA Risk Management resolution, and IA policy compliance for upgrades and improvement to the GBS system; Senior IA technical advisor to the Director, Information Security Directorate: Washington Headquarters Service (WHS) of the Office of the Secretary of Defense; C&A Security lead for the DFAS ELAN Re-Engineering Initiative, and IA security lead for the DISA GE65 PKI re-certification effort and provided security engineering technical support to NE21 via the DISA PMO Support contract. Knowledge areas: •Ability to work in and lead a team environment. •Develop strategic implementation plans for customer’s service vision activities. •Ability to perform strategic analysis; formulation and drafting strategic guidance. •Create requirements analysis, systems design, full life cycle development. •Collaboration across the customer organization to facilitate effective, efficient, and consistent business processes. •Identify barriers to progress, plan and implement effective and efficient problem-solving and corrective action plans. •Ability to formulate and translate user functional requirements and mission needs into technical terminology and specifications. •Participate in forums and meetings to invoke cross-agency and multi-agency collaboration

description: While employeed at SAIC I held positions of Deputy Division Manager, PM, Deputy PM, or Informatin Security lead engineer on numerous C4I (Classified) projects in support of national, DoD, NSA, Navy,and DISA programs. Principal IA engineer for the SAIC DISA sponsored Net-Centric Enterprise Services (NCES) IA implementation team; principle IA engineer for Joint Staff (J6I) IA engineering technical leadership and co-authored the Net Centric Operating Environment Joint Integrating Concept IA enabling Construct; principal IA Systems Security Engineer for the DISA Net-Centric Capabilities Pilot (NCCP) Core Services, NCCP Portal, User Defined Operating Picture, DSIDE, and Situational Awareness demonstration that was developed and accredited in the DISA SKY 7 facility; provided program management support, and technical engineering solutions the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) sponsored Integrated Weapons of Mass Destruction Tool (IWMDT) programs; principal IA engineer supporting the OSD HFES (QL-1) pilot and the JC2I Security engineering sub-contract to Northrop Grumman IT; principal IS engineer supporting the Marine Corps NMCI program at MARFORINO, Quantico, VA representing the Marine Corps at all executive level NMCI implementation sessions, co-chaired the Marine Corps NMCI technical working group; principal IA Engineer supporting the OSD C3I Data Mirroring Project; principal IA Security Engineer supporting the Advance Information Technology Systems-Joint program Office (AITS-JPO); senior IA Analyst providing technical and management support to the Joint Chiefs of Staff J6K Security operations providing hands-on, IA tech support for the GCCS, GCCS-T, and GCSS programs; and, program manager and Lead IA engineer in the development of a B-Spec for a classified overhead data processing system that when launched would provide near-real time intelligence to Naval forces at sea.

description: Naval Cryptologic Officer (LDO). Mr. Creighton served with pride and distinction in ships, submarines, and ashore SIGINT facilities of the US Navy throughout the world for 22 Years. The programs supported and experience gained during this period remain classified but cover SIGINT/ELINT/Space/All Source Data fusion requirements in support of meeting the tactical commanders intent and also included support to the National SIGINT/Intelligence community and local JCS,CINCLANT, SACLANT, and Second Fleet Navy Flag officer presentations and support. Mr. Creighton served in positions of increased responsibility ranging from E1 – E9, WO1 – CWO4, and O1- O3. Mr. Creighton’s last tour was the Department head for a department of Navy SIGINT special operations unit that provided mission support for a wide range of special requirements in support of national and navy tactical SIGINT operations world-wide.

Lead division as the lead Operator on DNI and SIGINT systems resulting in excellent mission sustainment. description: Serves as the primary USAREUR staff officer to training instrumentation systems, in particular the Deployable Instrumentation Systems Europe (DISE); supervises a section of seven authorized civilian, military personnel and contractors; manages the use, maintenance, and accountability of all DISE equipment and systems; responsible for providing training support operations for USAREUR units at home station and deployed training areas throughout Europe; coordinates DISE integration into unit training, provides government oversight of contractors, records management, and reporting; develops and coordinates short/long-term planning; develops and executes DISE’s operational budget; assists in the development of training policies and directives; serves as the Technical Oversight Representative (TOR) for an operations and maintenance contract. Performs other duties as required.

title: Protocol Officer
name: Fernando Torres

education.name: Albert Einstein HS, Santurce Puerto Rico

description: Serves as Protocol Officer with responsibility for planning, coordinating and execution of distinguished visitor operations within the Joint Multinational Training Command (JMTC), at Grafenwoehr Training Area, and the Joint Multinational Training Center (JMRC), at Hohenfels Training Area. Organizes official luncheons dinners, receptions and gatherings hosted by the Commanding General (CG) and/or Commander (COG) and is responsible for administrative and protocol procedures. The position requires utmost tact, diplomacy and professional competence, particularly during official functions and when providing advice and assistance to all levels of management. Must accurately analyze and evaluate comments, trends and suggestions pertaining to protocol functions and have the ability to make oral presentations and establish and maintain working relationships with U.S. Staff Officers as well as foreign dignitaries. Responsible for the health, welfare and accountability of 7 Soldiers, rates the performance of 3 non-commissioned officers and counsels the performance of 4 others. Supervise the utilization, maintenance and accountability of a 12 vehicle protocol fleet and organic equipment consisting of tactical and non-tactical vehicles worth in excess of $500 thousand.

description: Serves as a certified operator, trainer, and instructor for the battlefield computer simulation system software for the Joint Conflict and Tactical Simulation (JCATS). Replicates constructive elements from specialty platoon to Brigade Combat Team (BCT) level across all Battlefield Operating Systems (BOS). Conducts pre-exercise instrumentation checks on all simulations equipment at the TAF section of JMRC to ensure that all systems are functioning correctly and communicating with JMRC's Instrumentation System (JMRC-IS) in order to provide a realistic representation of the actual battlefield, role players, and scripted training scenarios. Doctrine and computer simulations Subject Matter Expert (SME) responsible for facilitating training for U.S. Army units and allied nations assigned to the European Command (EUCOM) in accordance with U.S. Army Doctrine and the Combat Training Center Methodology. Assists in the Planning and coordination of training site facilities, locations, personnel/equipment requirements, and layouts for exercise execution. Facilitates in the decision making process in order for the training unit(s) to gain confidence in communications, teamwork, and the leadership process in accordance with current U.S. Army Doctrine.

title: Operations Sergeant Major
name: Fernando Torres

education.name: Albert Einstein HS, Santurce Puerto Rico

description: Established and supervised a Squadron TOC, equipped with ABCS, FBCB2, BFT, FATDS, CPOF, JNN and BCS3 in a 1,200 Soldier Infantry Squadron. Synchronized the Battle Staff during training and combat operations and managed equipment worth in excess of $4 million. Supervised the planning, resourcing, and coordinated training support systems such as, RTLP, ITAM, EST, CFFT, DISE, LMTS, HEAT, MILES, and other training aids. Supervised the planning, resourcing, and participated in the execution of combat operations during a 15 months deployment to Iraq. Served as the Mayor of a Forward Operations Base (FOB) in Iraq. Responsible for the quality of life, Morale, Welfare and logistical support of a 2,250 personnel installation. Assist in formulation, coordination, and execution of operational, emergency and mobilization plans and policies during emergency operational tests, alerts and actions. Represent the unit in conferences and meetings. Led the Mobile Redistribution Team to salvage and return more than $3 million worth of supplies, parts, and property back into the Army’s supply system. Supervised the Accountability of the Installation level property with responsibilities and authority to exercise supervision over the FOB Property Book Management Team and a turn-in section involved in the accountability of all organization and installation property. As the COR, ensured cost effectiveness by expertly managing a $6.4 million security and force protection contract in Iraq, resulting in the early detection and defeat of possible insurgent attacks on FOB Normandy. Planned, designed, procured and managed a $5 million construction and facilities improvement contract resulting in the 100% Quality of Life improvements and cost effectiveness in Iraq. Planned, synchronized, assessed, evaluated and supervised the redeployment of 1,200 Soldiers and equipment worth in excess of $400 million from Iraq to Germany without incident, loss or damage.

title: Directorate of Training Sergeant Major
name: Fernando Torres

education.name: Albert Einstein HS, Santurce Puerto Rico

description: Supervised the Training Support Systems for the EUCOM AOR, including TADS, RTLP, ITAM, EST, Guard Fist, DISE and other training aids. Managed and solved the administrative requirements of 5 divisions consisting of JMTED HQ, Combined Arms Training Center (CATC), Training Support Activities Europe (TSAE), Plans and Operations Division (OPD) and Range Control and Operations at 5 geographically dispersed locations with a Soldier and civilian strength of 1,100 personnel. Planned, coordinated, resourced and conducted the unit's recognition, GWOT memorial, promotions, change of command, change of responsibility, activation, transfer of authority, award, and retirement ceremonies for HQs 7th JMTC. Reviewed operations plans and orders, policies, publications and provided feedback. Planned, coordinated, developed and supervised all functional and institutional training, doctrinal policies, and international NCO education program for the USAREUR command to include the Balkans. Planned and managed the USAREUR Army Force Generation (ARFORGEN) re-set for 2BCT, 1AD, 2BCT, 1ID and 173rd ABCT resulting in the education of 3,500 Soldiers. Planned, resourced and supervised 5 BNCOC MTTs from CONUS training 400 NCOs and proving cost effectiveness by saving more than $600 thousand. Supervised the training, pre-deployment, deployment and redeployment of 3 National Guards Task Forces to Kosovo for operations KFOR, 6B, KFOR 7, and KFOR 8. Planned, managed and synchronized the functional and institutional training and education of more than 12,000 U.S. and international Soldiers, NCOs and Officers. Planned, coordinated and executed distinguished visitors at Grafenwoehr Training Area including the CSA, SMA, USAREUR CDR and CSM, TRADOC CDR and CSM and many other U.S and International dignitaries. Conducted several professionally delivered briefings, training demonstrations and conferences depicting the JMTED capabilities to a myriad of U.S. and International dignitaries.

title: Senior Task Force NCO Advisor/Observer/Controller/Trainer
name: Fernando Torres

education.name: Albert Einstein HS, Santurce Puerto Rico

description: Supervised the training, administrative actions, health and welfare, certification and evaluation of an OCT consisting of Senior NCOs and Officers. Responsible for providing training, evaluation, validation and lessons learned on Combat Functions BOS, COIN operations, logistical support operations, convoy operations, transportation, technical, and procedural support to more than 15,000 U.S. and international Soldiers prior to their deployment to various countries to include Bosnia, Kosovo, Africa, Iraq and Afghanistan. Managed and supervised the near, short and long term rotational training calendar for his team. Developed instructions and standard operating procedures for maneuver and support battalions in transportation and fuel re-supply operations. Coached, mentored and advised commanders and subordinate leaders on the latest Tactics, Techniques and Procedures and evolving doctrine prior to their scheduled deployments. Managed the team’s Safety and Occupational Health program IAW laws, regulations, practices and procedures. Developed methods and techniques to control/prevent and minimize high-risk incidents and hazards during combat training. Frequently deploying to Iraq, Kosovo, Bosnia, and Afghanistan and conducted compliance inspections to identify deficiencies of deploying units, supervise and evaluate ground deployment operations to ensure units were following doctrinal standards. Possesses superb knowledge of military tactical operations, combat operations and experience in risk assessment, accident investigation, environmental principles, and operational mishap prevention programs. Supervised quality control, evaluated work performance and training requirements, and OHP of subordinates. Assisted on course development, development of training policies, technical procedures, correspondence, records, planning reports and special reports to USAREUR Headquarters. Supervised the accountability of all team property worth in excess of $500 thousand.

description: Progressed through increasing levels of responsibility with the U.S. Army and promoted to the rank of Colonel with accountability and responsibility for a 1000+ employee organization, geographically dispersed across the Western United States. Supervise, schedule, and mentor senior and mid-grade leaders and managers of a multi-faceted organization with specialized capabilities in governance, nation building, humanitarian assistance operations, and disaster relief operations within a global environment. Career Accomplishments and Highlights: • Combat Command of Provincial Reconstruction Team and Forward Operating Base in Farah, Afghanistan for 13 months. Responsible for over 160 US Military, US Civilian, and Local Nationals. Planned and executed civil-military operations to stabilize and develop the region, extend the reach of the Government of Afghanistan, and promote the rule of law. • Experience with Non-Governmental Organizations (NGO's), Private Volunteer Organizations (PVO's), and Special Operations environment in Afghanistan, Former Yugoslavia (Bosnia), Sri Lanka, Papua New Guinea, Republic of Korea, Mongolia, Thailand, and the Kingdom of Nepal. • Expertise in: Command, Control, Communications, Computers, Intelligence Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (C4ISR); Stability Operations/Low-Intensity Conflict (SOLIC), Foreign Internal Defense / Unconventional Warfare (FID/UW); and Civil-Military Operations (CMO). description: Primary point of contact and key resource to senior leadership and top management for all financial operations and to provide guidance on compliance with legal and regulatory authorities. Directing the day-to-day financial management activities for the Group and several large, complex, worldwide IT programs ranging between $35M-$55M, to balance program resources and optimize program objectives. Responsible for budget development, planning, guidance, preparation and updating of budget submissions, corresponding spend plans and coordinating strategic plans documents, regarding financial budget processes for the client's annual and multi-year budgets. Responding to data calls for resource information, budget justifications, assist in writing business cases and briefing material particularly for mid-year, zero base reviews and talking points. Providing general project management support, and financial training for the government. Support, develop and present executive level financial reports, briefings, data, and other documents providing program execution status, programming and acquisition strategy, identifying discrepancies, and recommending corrective actions for effective management and execution. Participate in discussions regarding project-related decisions and project direction at the executive level to provide financial support, approve special project funding requests and conduct analysis for trends affecting budget needs, develop budget projections, advise on the accuracy of budget forecasts to facilitate data driven decision making and to ensure that projects are operating within negotiated and agreed-upon parameters. Performed all aspects of program budget management, and analysis from cradle-to-grave. Involved in most aspects of the entire client department, organizing, managing and providing all the financial expertise necessary to ensure successful program execution.

description: Intelligence sector support at the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). Eight years in NSG supporting the Transport, EDGE and CORE Ground Fiber Programs within the Communications Directorate. Performing all facets of acquisition, finance support, special projects for senior managers, forecasting a 5-yr plan, and building the congressional budget (CBJB). Interacting directly with contracts, budget officers, technical representatives, PMs, contractor counterparts and their financial management. Coordinating contract funding actions and analyzing contractor monthly financial status reporting to include participating in all program management reviews and award fee briefings. Responsible for day-to-day budget activities of the project teams, consisting of tracking, accountability, internal/external funds from other components, government agencies and overseas, maintenance of various databases (IFMS/BERT/BART/SPA), current year funds and directly responsible for execution of requirements for (9) active contracts and several large, complex, global project/program budgets from $90-$124M. As well as, preparing numerous financial ad-hoc reports, OMB 300/53, and briefs to present to program/senior managers, comptroller, congressional staffers and multiple customers across the IC. Overseeing, the often-complex task of funds transfers between agencies, analyzing monthly contractor funds status reports, maintaining financial databases, and providing financial award fee comments. description: • Deployed throughout the Middle East and North Africa supporting HUMINT and Influence Operations mission activity as part of a a multi-disciplined Special Operations team; Coordinated between US Special Operations units and host nation counterparts to facilitate joint military operations. • Researched and analyzed target subgroups within the Middle East for Strategic Influence Operations and recommended non-kinetic campaigns to engage those groups in support of Operations Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom; identified opportunities for population and key leader engagement, PSYACTs, and influence operations. • Responsible for managing assets for multi-lingual printed, radio, and television media; coordinated all administrative aspects and designed incentive program to promote more accurate, resonate translations of US Strategic Influence messaging. • Chaired media Concept Development and Review (CDR) boards, using cultural factor analysis to challenge “strategic messaging” themes and approaches; ensured that media products resonated with the target audience while reflecting National Security Policy and promoting US demarche in the region. • Collaborated with partners in Special Missions and the Intelligence Community to produce of multiple, highly-successful Joint Influence Operations campaigns in the Middle Eastern Gulf, Levant, and Horn of Africa. • Served as Senior Cultural Advisor to a PSYOP command during multiple major influence operation campaigns in the Middle East and Southwest Asia; aided in selecting campaign themes, PSYOP objectives, and approaches to promote US interests in Iraq and Afghanistan which resonated with selected segments of ethnically and culturally diverse audiences • Specially selected to support military assistance programs in Middle East and Horn of Africa to facilitate joint SOF missions in the region

title: CEO
name: Andy Eadie

groups.name: high speed board design and development
EMC System Engineering & Industry Standards for Electric Vehicle Technology

description: I created EMC FastPass with a sole mission: To help electronic design companies get through EMC and RF certifications faster and cheaper. I was a senior hardware design engineer for many years and took a trip to the dark side and founded an FCC listed EMC test lab (Island Labs). I got to learn the ins and outs of EMC and RF testing as both a design engineer and a lab manager. I can really appreciate the industry's frustration with the EMC/RF testing process. Using this knowledge, my aim is to assist the electronics design industry to focus on making products that make money, and minimize the impact of regulatory red tape wherever possible. To achieve this, EMC FastPass offers the tools, information and assistance that you need to accelerate your product launch. Some services that EMC FastPass offers: - EMC design reviews (Comprehensive reviews for emissions and immunity) - Wireless product launch packages - Non-wireless product launch packages - Consulting and advice (on a retainer basis) - EMC troubleshooting - Online video courses (coming soon) - Online design review software (coming soon) See www.emcfastpass.com/services for more details.

description: Young Professionals of Comox Valley promotes social interaction, professional development and community Involvement. Our members are all under 40 and include entreprenuers, employees and students. As the head of professional development, I coordinate opportunities for our members to learn from a broad range of topics spanning web development, SEO, sales and marketing, motivation and community participation skills as well as providing networking opportunities such as speed networking and industry parntnership opportunities.

description: Island Labs offers Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) testing and certification services to local and international manufacturers. Our open area test site (OATS) is registered with the FCC and Industry Canada which enables us to perform testing on a wide variety of products including wireless, medical, power, consumer and telecoms to name a few. We also undertake the testing required to prove compliance with the EMC directive for CE Marking your product. Our leading edge EMC hardware design support adds value by helping our clients get it right first time. Our industry leading EMC design review has a 95% success rate in assisting clients pass emissions testing on the first pass.

description: TEDx was created in the spirit of TED's mission, "ideas worth spreading." The program is designed to give communities, organizations and individuals the opportunity to stimulate dialogue through TED-like experiences at the local level. At TEDx events, a screening of TEDTalks videos -- or a combination of live presenters and TEDTalks videos -- sparks deep conversation and connections. TEDx events are fully planned and coordinated independently, on a community-by-community basis.
